abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the Bulgaria Railway
            Rehabilitation Project are as follows: Project outcome is
            moderately satisfactory; sustainability is non-evaluable;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. The following lessons may be drawn from the
            experience of this project:: 1)  Rationalizing subsidy
            support and introducing appropriate traffic costing models
            are important pre-requisites to restoring the long-term
            financial health of state-owned railway companies and moving
            them towards commercial operation. 2) It is critical to the
            success of a complex undertaking such as the installation of
            an integrated Management Information System that sufficient
            technical supervision and support be made available to
            assist with resolving problems as they arise. 3) An
            integrated Management Information System may be too complex
            an undertaking to implement as a single package in a
            transitioning economy; consideration should be given to a
            phased design approach. 4)  Public Service Obligation
            Subsidy should be for specific services that the government
            considers socially necessary; such social services should be
            transparent, explicitly defined and fully compensated as
            part of a Contract Plan.

6073696.trustfund:
TF026080-USTDP ENVIRONMENTAL
            CONSL'T TRUST FUND,TF032104-BULGARIA - RAILWAY RESTRUCTURING,TF033930-BULGARIA - TRANSPORT, RAILWAYS,TF040621-ROMANIA - RAILWAYS AND BULGARIA
            RAILWAY REHAB PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            and project sustainability is rated as likely. The
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower were
            rated satisfactory, overall. Lessons learned can be grouped
            into four categories and concerned policy reforms and the
            lending instrument; the design of the major information
            technology project component; the optimization of track
            renewal sub-projects; and the relationships between project
            components. Project design made the Bank a legitimate
            partner of the Bulgarian State Railway (BDZ) and the
            government in transforming the railway sector over the
            project period and provided key targets on which the debate
            could focus. This was reinforced from 1999 on by the
            visibility given to railway reforms by the IMF stabilization
            program as well as the Bank's own growing concern with
            structural adjustment and initiation of a broad programmatic
            adjustment lending approach. But the opportunity offered by
            the stabilization and adjustment programs could not have
            been taken, had a strong relationship not been established
            between the Bank, BDZ, and the Government through investment
            lending. The excruciating experience in implementing the
            project component aimed at establishing new management
            information systems and the eventual failure of this
            component cast doubt on the approach adopted in its design.
            The approach was to use international turnkey contractors to
            put together and install major systems. The radical nature
            of the changes, the lack of a trial and error process, the
            speed of decision making made necessary by the contract
            implementation process, the high stakes but also uncertain
            basis on which to make decisions, and the differences
            between the contractors and their supervisors within BDZ
            were such that an adversarial relationship was almost
            unavoidable and could not be mitigated by a strong common
            agreement on the ultimate objectives to be achieved.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Railway Rehabilitation Project will
            support and deepen the restructuring process which the
            Railways and Government have initiated. The project supports
            a set of policy measures that will be embodied in new
            railway law, the Restructuring Action Plan and a Contract
            Plan with the Government. The project will finance necessary
            investments which will be in line with the restructuring
            concept and will help the railway through the restructuring
            process. This includes: (a) track renewal and maintenance on
            priority routes; (v) management information systems; (c)
            signalling and telecommunications; (d) traction and rolling
            stock improvements; (e) rehabilitation of passenger coaches;
            and (f) training and technical assistance.
